articles.headline: The Tiny Leader of the Pack
articles.snippet: Reva, which has been making stubby electric cars for eight years, may be the dark horse of the industry.
articles.abstract: Reva, which has been making stubby electric cars for eight years, may be the dark horse of the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India  Depending on whom you ask, this tiny company is either the next big thing in automobiles, or a maker of glorified golf carts.

articles.headline: Weight Gain Associated With Antipsychotic Drugs
articles.snippet: Children and adolescents gained an average of one to one-and-a-half pounds a week, a large study found.
articles.abstract: Children and adolescents gained an average of one to one-and-a-half pounds a week, a large study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Young children and adolescents who take the newest generation of antipsychotic medications risk rapid weight gain and metabolic changes that could lead to diabetes, hypertension and other illnesses, according to the biggest study yet of first-time users of the drugs.

articles.headline: U.S. to Protect Populous Afghan Areas, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The approach would stop short of an all-out assault on the Taliban while still seeking to nurture long-term stability.
articles.abstract: The approach would stop short of an all-out assault on the Taliban while still seeking to nurture long-term stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Thom Shanker, Peter Baker and Helene Cooper.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, Peter Baker and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Bill Seeks to Shift Rescue Costs to Big Banks
articles.snippet: Legislation would let the government shift the cost of saving troubled firms from taxpayers to other companies.
articles.abstract: Legislation would let the government shift the cost of saving troubled firms from taxpayers to other companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and the head of an important House committee unveiled legislation on Tuesday to give the government broad new powers to shift the cost of rescues of big, troubled financial institutions from taxpayers to other large companies.

articles.headline: A Drop in the Wrong Bucket
articles.snippet: The president has proposed sending a $250 check to every Social Security recipient, but some economists recoil.
articles.abstract: The president has proposed sending a $250 check to every Social Security recipient, but some economists recoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you wanted to help the economy and you had $14 billion to bestow on any group of people, which group would you choose:

articles.headline: Brother of Afghan Leader Said to Be Paid by C.I.A.
articles.snippet: Ahmed Wali Karzai, the brother of President Hamid Karzai and a suspected player in the opium trade, has gotten payments from the C.I.A. for eight years, American officials said.
articles.abstract: Ahmed Wali Karzai, the brother of President Hamid Karzai and a suspected player in the opium trade, has gotten payments from the C.I.A. for eight years, American officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Ahmed Wali Karzai, the brother of the Afghan president and a suspected player in the country’s booming illegal opium trade, gets regular payments from the Central Intelligence Agency, and has for much of the past eight years, according to current and former American officials.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins, Mark Mazzetti and James Risen

articles.headline: Big Lender GMAC Asks for More U.S. Aid
articles.snippet: The move by the troubled onetime financing arm of General Motors could give the government a majority stake in GMAC.
articles.abstract: The move by the troubled onetime financing arm of General Motors could give the government a majority stake in GMAC.
articles.lead_paragraph: GMAC, the troubled consumer finance company, is seeking billions of dollars in additional federal aid, a move that would be its third taxpayer bailout and could give the government a majority stake in the company, according to people briefed on the situation.
articles.byline:
By MICHAEL J. de
la MERCED and ERIC DASH

articles.headline: Clinton Arrival in Pakistan Met by Fatal Attacks
articles.snippet: An explosion in Peshawar left as many as 101 dead and underscored the challenges facing U.S. policymakers as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton came to Islamabad.
articles.abstract: An explosion in Peshawar left as many as 101 dead and underscored the challenges facing U.S. policymakers as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton came to Islamabad.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Militants in Pakistan and Afghanistan punctuated Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s arrival here with deadly attacks on Wednesday, underscoring their ability to cause chaos even in the face of offensives on both sides of the border.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ismail Khan

articles.headline: Hurting Rivals, Google Unveils Free Phone GPS
articles.snippet: Google’s service could chip away at sales of stand-alone GPS devices and the subscription services offered by cellphone carriers.
articles.abstract: Google’s service could chip away at sales of stand-alone GPS devices and the subscription services offered by cellphone carriers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  GPS navigation devices were the latest must-have tech toys just two years ago, and shares of device makers like Garmin and TomTom were soaring.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Miguel Helft
